event: Earliest evidence of human habitation on Trinidad by Archaic peoples.
Saladoid peoples from South America settle both Trinidad and Tobago.
Island inhabited by Arawak and Carib-speaking peoples.
Christopher Columbus lands on Trinidad during his third voyage.
Spanish begin colonization of Trinidad, though limited settlement occurs for decades.
San José de Oruña founded as the first Spanish settlement in Trinidad.
Cedula of Population encourages French immigration and African slavery to Trinidad.
British forces capture Trinidad from Spain.
Treaty of Amiens formalizes British control of Trinidad.
British begin formal administration of Trinidad.
Tobago administratively united with Trinidad as a single colony.
Slavery abolished in the British Empire; emancipation of enslaved Africans.
First major labor unrest and formation of workers' organizations.
Universal suffrage introduced in Trinidad and Tobago.
Eric Williams forms the People’s National Movement (PNM), leading push for independence.
Trinidad and Tobago gains independence from the United Kingdom on August 31.
Black Power Revolution sparks social unrest; government declares state of emergency.
Trinidad and Tobago becomes a republic within the Commonwealth.
Jamaat al Muslimeen stages a failed coup attempt, holding government hostage for six days.
Kamla Persad-Bissessar becomes the country’s first female Prime Minister.
COVID-19 pandemic affects economy, particularly energy and tourism sectors.
